captions.text:
Kids, you just have
it all handed to you.

And let me just
tell you something,
it's all about kittens.

Kittens, kittens--
oh, I want a kitten.
So sweet.

Please, let me have a little
ball of fuzz, a little kitten.
What about the older guys?
What about them?

Let me tell you something,
youngster, you better

go out there and
catify the world!
Now, get out of here.

Yesterday I went to this
wonderful woman's house, Janet.
Hi Janet.
She's fantastic.
She's a great artist.

And she's also a caretaker for
many elderly and special needs
cats and dogs.

I mainly wanted to
talk a little bit

today about the benefits
of adopting an older cat,

slash dog, slash pony,
slash bunny, whatever.

First of all, they demand
less and they give more.

That I can tell you by
my experience, and maybe

my friend Janet, and
anybody else who specializes
in older animals.

They can tell you, man,
these guys are grateful.

You will find that the love that
you get from an older animal
is just unparalleled.

And I'm not just
saying this, guys,

I'm not just saying
this because I

want to go out there and be just
like my friend Janet yesterday.

And take the hard to place guys,
take the ones that are older,

take the ones that may
have higher vet bills.
Yeah.

I mean I get it, it might
be an inconvenience.

And also psychologically
may be very tough for you.

But that said, the payback
is absolutely immense.

Secondly, by and
large, they tend

to be less willfully
destructive.

Less in the way of marking, or
if they don't get their way,

they pee somewhere and they
can scratch up everything.

Now, of course, they may
have physical problems

that we see manifest
in older cats.

But in terms of
behavioral problems,

I see a lot less when it
comes to older versus kittens,
teenagers, and middle age.

So let's talk about older
cats and your household.

If you work a lot,
you don't really

want a kitten in your
house, or a teenager.

They're going to be
demanding of you.

You've seen me do a lot
of videos on play therapy,
on getting energy out of cats.

A 9-year-old, 10-year-old
cat, you don't really

have to worry that much about
constantly entertaining them.

Of course, we want to keep
them mentally stimulated,

and physically
stimulated as well.

But that doesn't mean
they demand it the way
younger cats do.

Once you get to
a certain age, it

is about the path
of least resistance.

And that makes for a much
calmer house for the most part.

Because instead of hunt, catch,
kill, eat, groom, and sleep,

it's like watch someone
else hunt, catch, and kill.

And then you can eat
and groom and sleep.

That is the life
of an older cat.

That's like what cat
retirement is all about.

Another advantage to an
older animal in your home--

when you get an older
cat, a senior cat, you
know what you're getting.

You know if they have a history
with other cats or dogs.

You know how tolerant they
are of children, for instance.

You know how they'll
integrate into your house,
or not integrate.

When you get a
kitten, you're not

sure what you're getting,
in terms of the personality.

So what you see is
kind of what you get,
as opposed too much younger cat.

If I were an 8,
9-year-old cat sitting

in your house, the
last thing that I

would want-- the
last thing-- would

be a kitten-- that
ball of energy.

And we're not just
talking kitten,

we're talking about up to
about a year and a half old,

that energy level will just
drive a middle aged or senior
cat to distraction.

So why not set them up with
someone of their own age?

We do have a problem
in terms of housing
older animals in this world.

I mean, we've got animals
that are doing behaviorally

and physically less
well the longer they
stay in the shelter.

And, with older age, we
see less of an ability
to fight things off like that.
Plus, they're less popular.

They're not going to
get adopted as fast.

You have open admission
shelters that are unfortunately
killing these cats.

And you've got selective
admission shelters

that say, yeah, we really can't
do much with your 12-year-old

because I don't
know if we're going

to be able to get
him out of here.

That's the reality
the situation, folks.

We did touch on
this a little bit--

is there a quote
unquote "downside"?

if you are adopting
an older animal,

you should be able to take care
of that cat, dog, or whomever.

And that means that the
vet bills will be higher.

You do have to commit to
bringing your senior cat
in for an annual wellness exam.

Now, I know I can
get in to your head
when it comes to your psyche.

If you had a kitten
sitting here,

or teenager cat, and an
older cat-- and you say,
I'm going to take the kitten.

And why is it you
take that kitten?

Well, first of
all, you don't want

to be faced with that
animal's mortality.

You just don't want to give
your heart to an animal

that you might lose
sooner than later.
I get that.

But, again, we're talking
about expanding out
our circle of compassion.

The second thing is people
are under the mistaken notion

that bringing in a kitten into
a home with existing animals
will be easier.

There's no hard and
fast about that.

Because they will be
teenagers soon enough,

they're going to cause
havoc in your home.

And you're going to have an
easier time, in my opinion

and in my experience, with an
older versus a younger cat.

And the other
thing is, you think

you might be able to
mold them into the shape

that you would like
them to be, as opposed

to the concept of teaching
an old cat, or an old dog,
new tricks.
We all know that's not the case.

Just because a cat, or
a dog, or anybody else

has certain set
routines doesn't mean
we can change them over time.

But in the meantime, can we look
past the cute cuddly kittens?

Again, I've talked
about this a lot--

the concept of expanding
your circle of compassion--

about saying well, if I love
this cute little cuddly kitten,

do I love this
8-year-old sitting

here in the cage next
to the cuddly kitten?

There are so many advantages
to bringing home an older cat.

Now, let me just make one
more little caveat here--

just because I'm singing the
praises of older animals today

does not mean I'm telling
you not to take home
the kittens and the teenagers.
They all need homes, folks.
They all need homes.

I think in a very
big sense though,

if there's an older animal
sitting in the shelter

or rescue that you know
of, they need that home

a little bit worse
right about now.

Hey, by the way,
people are still

asking me the
supermarket questions.

They're asking me very
simple behavioral questions

that, guess what, I've already
addressed on this very show
on "Cat Mojo."

If you will just take a
look back over old episodes,

you'll see that I touch
on a lot of the question
that you guys might have.

For instance, about catifying
your home, the confident where.

If you talk about introducing
cat to cat, plenty of things

that you might be having trouble
with, I've already addressed.

So make sure that if you find a
question on Twitter or Facebook

from somebody else who's
getting really frustrated,

guide them back to old
episodes of "Cat Mojo."

and maybe we'll help
keep those cats in homes.

And by the way, if there
is a supermarket question

that I haven't answered
yet, well then by all means,

please don't hit me
up at the supermarket,

hit me up at
hashtag TeamCatMojo.
And that's that.

All right folks,
until next time,

when we speak, which will
be-- oh, in just about

a week's time-- be
good to yourselves,

be good to the
animals in your lives,

and adopt yourself
an older cats,

slash dog, slash pony, slash
bunny, slash something today,
OK?
All right.

Until next time, all light,
all love, all mojo to you.
Love you guys.
THEME SONG: I'm not a bad cat--
You're a bad cat--
I'm not a bad cat--
You're a bad cat--
I'm just misunderstood.

title: The One Thing to Know Before Adopting a Cat

comments.text:
I adopted an older cat he's 7.. I got him when he was 6... (although I knew 
him for a few years).. anyway.. I prefer the older cats. they do their own 
thing. they are less likely to jump out and attack ankles which I dislike. 
I had zero training with this cat he was already litter box trained etc etc 
and I can just enjoy him instead of putting the effort in. sounds bad but 
it works for me. I doubt I would ever adopt a kitten﻿
comments.author: Stef Rose (Stef's Games)

comments.text:
Unfortunately, i'm not capable of adopting any cat for 3 reasons.
1: I only make enough money to support myself
2: I don't have enough space in my home
3: I live in an apartment where i'm not allowed to have Pets :(﻿
comments.author: phoenixfirex

comments.text:
If the world would buy older cats, there would be a lack to breed as much 
but the truth behind it is just:
Old cats used to be kittens that werent adopted.
By adopting a kitten you give it a forever home (hopefully)
By adopting a kitten you get more attached
But I am 97% for adopting older cats. They're all loveable...

Sadly I am in a family who wants a kitte after our 14 yr old died.﻿
comments.author: Mimi-Chi Rios

comments.text:
Hey Jackson, there is an awesome kids book called Lets Get a Pup, and it's 
about this little girl called Kate and her family that go to a shelter to 
look for a puppy. they see a cute puppy and are about to take him home, 
when they see Rosy, who looks like she doesnt have much longer to live. the 
family goes home, but comes back the next day to take her home too :D﻿
comments.author: Kire Moonchild

comments.text:
Spot on. If you're the type of person that's project-oriented, and doesn't 
like interruptions all the time (which may be why you're not a fan of kids) 
then getting a puppy or kitten will drive you nuts. But an older cat just 
wants to hang out and see what you're doing. Main issue is you inherit what 
past owners have done to the pet. Our dog was 3 when we got him, and 
previous owner must have hit him. When he hears someone raise their voice 
he goes and hides. Plus, he changed hands a few times before us, and has 
abandonment issues. I think people moved and couldn't afford pet deposits 
at apartments, because when we moved twice he was very anxious. Probably 
thought we were gonna dump him off to a new person. Even our kitten is a 
bit abandonment. He and a sister were found as strays. Not sure what 
happened to mother cat. A lady fostered them, then adopted them out at 
shelter. His sister was adopted first, then we adopted him later that day. 
He lost his mom, his sister and his foster parent. We notice that if my gf 
or I leave, he's quick to go snuggle with whoever is still at home.﻿
comments.author: therandomdot

comments.text: God how i love your old cat <3333333333 how old is he/she? What race? :)﻿
comments.author: JE ENN

comments.text: I love Jackson Galaxy. He is awesome!
comments.author: Bettie Page (BettiePageGaming)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9JcB5fLAKbk #teamcatmojo  
#lapcatsanonymous  ﻿
comments.author: Cat Friends of Minnesota

comments.text:
I did take in kitten, but I prefer older cats...
But this kitten was close to death :(
She had a lot of illness and still has a lot of problems...
T-T Give up my bed to have her [Been sleeping on the floor for 7 months now 
to make sure she got all she needed]
But I love her and hearing her purr now and on the day I first got her 
makes me smile
X3
Don't regret taking my little kitten in [she not 6 months old]
But if I had not gotten her or met her 4 months ago I would taken in a 
older cat, love older cats and can't wait for my kitten to be 2-3 years old 
xD﻿
comments.author: Sabrina Nolasco

comments.text:
I have a kitten and an adult cat. I used to have 6 cats until we gave 4 of 
the kittens away to good homes. Both are amazing, anybody is crazy saying a 
kitten is worse and an older cat is better, or the other way around.﻿
comments.author: A Very very very very very sexual walrus

comments.text:
When I was 8, I got an older male cat, and he is the sweetest cat ever. He 
also raised my two younger cats that we got at different times. Now, all of 
our cats are well behaved, well mannered, and friendly!﻿
comments.author: LetsTalkAbout Life

comments.text:
+LetsTalkAbout Life Oh, and by younger cats, I mean we got them when they 
were babies.
comments.author: LetsTalkAbout Life

comments.text:
Against my better judgement I'm starting to like Jackson. I say my better 
judgement because I judged him by his cover (my bad). We have a teenage 
stray Tom that decided he lived with us. I was completely against another 
cat as we already have two but this little guy just stole my heart. That 
and he chose me. Anyway we're having him neutered in a couple days and then 
we're introducing him to our pet family. Wish us luck.﻿
comments.author: Grinthor86

comments.text:
The ONLY reason I started with a kitten ( I really really really wanted a 
old cat) was because I found her in a Tralee park dirty,homeless,and 
STARVING so I took her in ( I'm the ONLY person she trusts!!!) it is a 
beautiful reward. But please adopt animal that are hard to place like 
elders.the time might be short,but it will be worth it to see a cat die in 
a home and not a shelter :-)﻿

Thank you. We're thinking of adopting and we'll definitely get an older cat 
(or two).﻿

comments.text: Should I get a cat from a pet store because I feel bad for them﻿

If you take home the kitten you'd better be ready to keep it to eight and

that reptile looks like it could eaten a kitten like that if it get the

comments.author: FreakyHydra

comments.text:
once ive moved out ill be adopting grey hounds, the greyhound racing 
industry is disgusting and one of the worst animal sports ever to exist... 
My kitten i have now is only 13 weeks, i raised him and 3 others from under 
a week old fostering for my work, two were separated due to illness 
(although they are alive and have been adopted together) and one of the two 
i was looking after passed away to what i believe was coccidia, so because 
i have only one i foster failed and im keeping him <3 almost lost the 
bugger twice. He's the best thing to ever happen to me :) and i love that i 
can say that i raised him since he was only days old (was a lot of work 
though, still havent caught up on my sleep and its been almost a month when 
i stopped waking up to feed him)﻿
comments.author: tigger1995Magi

comments.text:
I took on my beautiful girl when was 3.5 after having her second litter. 
 They'd been finding her really difficult to adopt out.  She's loving and 
calm, and she has taken to sleeping curled up right against me.  So happy I 
went with her.﻿
comments.author: Julia Mackenzie

comments.text:
They should come with a warning letting the new owner that they have to be 
vigilant 24 hours a day. Cats are exceedingly good at training people. :)﻿

comments.text:
I wish I could adopt another cat but there aren't any places around my area

comments.author: Drag Black

comments.text: Go to gumtree
comments.author: Aisha Maham

comments.text:
I adopted my cat Mrs.Mew (originally named praline) at petco. She was 2 
years at dumb friends leaugs approximation. Had her for two years first 
couple days she was a bit of a wallflower but we got her some cat-furniture 
that our previous cat, who had passed away, hadnt come into contact with. 
At first there where some problems but with rewards for good behavior, 
detourans for unwanted behavior, and a bit of time, she is now a happy 
adult mojito cat. Except for the weekly bath....she hates that bit. However 
she's come to terms with it (hopefully she realized it ahrinks her giant 
haurballs)﻿
comments.author: sakurachan105theII

comments.text:
hey umm my cat is 5 ( in human years ) so is that an adult because she rlly 
just hangs in the sun and isnt rlly hiper﻿
comments.author: AJcupcake lover

comments.text:
I have two amazing almost for year old cats I have raised since 8 weeks. 
Neither of them are aggressive except with each other. They are scared of 
other cats that enter the yard . They never became aggressive but they are 
defensive if needed. They are inside babies now. Both when seeing a kitten 
at the vets office seemed curious. The kittens were in the cages waiting to 
be adopted and both my babies seemed very interested not threatened or 
aggravated at all. An adult cat entered our yard and was clearly trying to 
befriend them and they were simply scared. Would it still be a good idea if 
I was to adopt another cat to go for an older cat? ﻿
comments.author: Jill Linkous

comments.text:
+Jill Linkous true I'm used to my kitten lol not even fazed by the car but 
that's because I fostered him from a week. You could always do a two trial 
:) take a cat home for a week or two and see how that goes
comments.author: tigger1995Magi

comments.text:
That would stress mine out completely. My boy moans so heartbreaking In the 
car. Taking them anywhere accept the vet is not an option . Luckily mine 
never have been sick so vet only for yearly checkups. And it breaks my 
heart . But nice idea though.
comments.author: Jill Linkous

comments.text:
You could always take your cats to a shelter/rescue group and put them in a 
private room to meet a cat and see how that goes. Some times getting a cat 
to meet its new family member at home can often not work out very well. If 
things seem if iffy but your heart is set on a certain cat than you can try 
and do regular visits just to get them used to each other that way. Maybe 
swapping them around in carrier, i.e. your cats are able to walk around a 
cat in a carrier and then vica versa
comments.author: tigger1995Magi

comments.text:
I am fostering a senior cat considered unadoptable. She has stiff joints 
and a chronic facial cyst. I drain the cyst at home. She has a couple of 
companion stuffed animals she grooms. Alice is so sweet, purrs so much and 
loves to be petted. My other cat was adopted out to someone else after her 
owner died. She was abandoned when the other person left town. I tracked 
her down at the shelter and she is a joyful companion. Lots of purring, 
birdwatching together and pleasant comaraderie. What a lucky lifetime for 
me to have these blessed four legged pets. When I think of senior cats for 
me it is about quality of life rather than quantity of life. I trust the 
animals and spirit in the innate wisdom of the natural perfection. I look 
forward to being greeted on the rainbow bridge by my beloveds.﻿
comments.author: Karen Lee

comments.text:
I adopted an 8 year old cat earlier this week. He's fantastic! He was 
already trained to walk on a leash and loves going for walks. He's sleeping 
in my lap right now :)﻿
comments.author: oberhartrl14

comments.text:
The one thing everyone forgets about older animals is the fact that they 
have less time on this earth. To give your love to them for those next good 
few years, is the most precious thing they will ever have, think about 
dying alone, knowing only one thing loved you and it left you behind. 
Wouldn't you be heartbroken? To have someone else come along and love you 
once again, wouldn't that make you happy? ﻿
comments.author: TheIceWeilder

comments.text: whats that blinking on your neck?﻿

comments.text:
my cats about 10 years old and absolutely LOVES chasing lasers. its so cute 
and funny seeing such a large cat bouncing around like a kitten.

and dont worry, the laser is not very powerful and i keep it away from his 
eyes.﻿

comments.text:
My experience with an eight year old cat has been great! I agree with you

comments.text:
I do not care how a cat looks, sure it would be better if they had that, 
but I prefer a friendly cat as a great companion.﻿

comments.author: manga4774

comments.text: What age is a teen cat? 1 year???﻿
comments.author: Vivi33

comments.text: About 2 or 3 years
comments.author: annabelle price

comments.text:
Interesting story... It all starts out with Kali, a nine year old (now 
fourteen) female cat that was spayed and declawed before I got her. She had 
a history of shock collars, which left a scar on the side of her neck and 
made her meow sound more crackly and gravelly. She also has larger fangs. 
Most of my friends are terrified of her, until they really get to MEET her. 
She is the most loving, adorable and awesome cat I've ever had. She loves 
to sleep on feet, loves getting belly rubs (usually only from me, until she 
gets to know others), loves to just be a lap cat and watch television.

Alright, moving on a couple years. I adore her, play with her daily, giving 
her everything I can.. but she starts getting lethargic and slow moving. 
She sleeps a lot more, and isn't nearly as cuddly. I figured, why not try a 
friend? We introduced her to three other cats, an older female, an younger 
female, and a teenage female. All of which she didn't get along with, and 
all of which found better homes where they weren't constantly fighting with 
the queen of the house. I decided, enough is enough, we'll just have to 
figure out something else. Now, all of the times I was introducing the 
females to Kali, I was doing it the 'proper way' that I was told to- 
separating them, slowly introducing them to each other, and then trading 
out different smells of one another.

Now, normally I don't want a kitten. They're noisy, messy, (adorable, yes) 
and high energy. I didn't want a male cat because I was scared he would 
spray. But just one more time, my wife says, just try it one more time. So, 
I agreed, but under one condition- try a male kitten. To me, this sounded 
like doomsday, but I had an odd feeling. Craigslist was offering a kitten 
at a local trailer park, and upon meeting him, he instantly went over to me 
and wouldn't leave without me. I took him home, and started setting up the 
usual separation barriers, before I paused. It hadn't worked the last few 
times. I took a chance, and opened up the carrier, and to my surprise, Kali 
went right over to him. She instantly started to clean him, and he started 
playing with her. I named him Charlie, and he is Kali's best friend. She 
stopped being lethargic, she stopped being secluded. They play together, 
eat together and sleep together. It's been almost a year and six months 
now, and they're still just as close. As for me, I love Charlie. I didn't 
think I could handle a kitten, but I found out I could. He doesn't spray, 
and is the 'man of the house'.﻿
comments.author: Kimmi Cat

comments.text:
This is how the dude from Moscow Cat Circus trains his cats - he adopts 
them as strays and they are so damn grateful that they learn his tricks!﻿
comments.author: spidaminida

comments.text: You sound like that lemon guy from adventure time. ﻿
comments.author: Pixel

comments.text:
All in all I'm not a big fan of kittens as my pet, sure they're cute but I 
don't get the feeling to want such a ball of energy if I don' t even have 
the time to raise it, to play with it and all. I very much prefer older 
cats, they're calm (most at least ;) and you can already tell that the cat 
will go along with a lazy-day :)﻿
comments.author: Neko Ko

comments.text:
Thanks, Jackson, for all you do! I just discovered this channel a couple 
days ago. I love watching My Cat From Hell. I don't have Animal Planet but 
I catch up on Netflix. I feel like I won the cat jackpot. I adopted my cats 
~8 years ago when a friend discovered two litters in her NorCal barn. She 
had ~12 kittens running around her property and was determined to find good 
homes for them all. I took two. I had gone to visit over Memorial Day; they 
weren't yet weaned. Over Labor Day I brought them home. In the meantime, as 
I had never had cats before, I decided I needed some practical cat handling 
experience, so I went and volunteered at the Seattle Humane Society. I 
learned a lot about cat behavior and how they differ from dogs (I had an 
elderly Akita/Lab mix at the time). Through that volunteer experience I met 
"Mama" Chloe, a Russian Blue, who was a bit older and had a calm demeanor. 
After a some internal debate, I decided I had to bring her home. I must 
have encountered dozens of cats during that time but I really connected 
with her. She essentially trained the kittens. I almost feel like we 
co-parent them. I've never had a behavioral problem with any of them. They 
all came home at about the same time and they adore each other. I was lucky 
that the senior volunteer I worked with at the shelter taught me a lot of 
the things you teach on your show and through other media like Cat Mojo. 
That experience really prepared me for life with cats and made all our 
lives richer. I would recommend that anyone considering a first time cat 
adoption spend some time volunteering at a shelter. It's invaluable 
experience. And yes, if you have the resources, there are great older cats 
that would so appreciate a loving home. Cheers, Anita﻿
comments.author: Anita Roberts

comments.text:
My current older cat is a retiree from my breeder... It was nice to bring 
her in my home, because I was able to choose a cat that would integrate in 
my household and be at ease with the other animals. At that time, I had an 
older maine coon lady suffering from IRC (kidney disease), and a slighty 
younger cat, I adopted after my uncle passed away... And I chose this lady 
to be a nice addition and a nice company for them... I do not regret this 
choice, she is a lovely lady and I love her, just as much as my lady cat, I 
got, when a kitten...
After the two other cats passed away, My retired lady was pretty lonely and 
desperate... I got my young dog, and I started thinking about bringing a 
new cat home, but I was not sure I was ready to have kitten mischiefs in my 
house again...
I finally chose a kitten at my breeder, already 5 months and a half... Her 
temperament was sweet and mischievous, and she was really social, and her 
type fit the standards of the breed.
My retired lady does like to observe the dog from a safe spot, she is nice 
to him and have soft paws... and the dog learnt respect from her...
The young lady, was adopted right away by my older one... she cares for 
her, as if she was her own kitten...
The next addition to the family will be a kitten as I intend to breed my 
young lady...
But one day, I may again adopt a retired cat from my breeder...
(and if you ask, why not from the shelter... well, that is because I am a 
big fan of maine coon cats and I really love their temperament... and also, 
because, as much as I adored my uncle cat who used to be a stray, he did 
have lot of medical issues... and I do not want to take the risk for the 
other pets of the house to bring them diseases)

But I do agree, older cats are a very wise choice, and you do love them as 
much as a kitten, when your heart is full of love...
They understand real quick all the rules of the house, and they are just as 
trainable (if not more, as they are more focused) than the kitten...﻿
comments.author: Pecky ShiFrit

comments.text:
I prefer older animals. Puppies and kittens have wayyyyy too much energy. 
I like chilled out older pets :)﻿

This was why when I was adopting a kid frim world vision, I chose the

waiting the longest.

comments.text: What on your neck﻿

comments.text: Good work always Jackson :)﻿
comments.author: Daniel Land

comments.text:
I always thought it was easier for my adult cat to accept a kitten! Now I 
know better.
Anyway I just adopted a black cat that was abandoned in a box on the street 
and don't know how old is he, the vet said like 2/3 years, and my other cat 
is 2, they got along pretty well in no time! 
Thank Jackson #TeamCatMojo  #AdoptDontShop !!﻿
comments.author: nosoynadaoriginal

comments.text:
my girl Leanne is a senior and I wouldn't do without her - she loves me 
like no other. She is a cuddle-bug and she often can want cuddles more than 
food. And she looooves food. She's a rescue girl and she's so thankful to 
be able to sit in the sun and look out the window. I thoroughly recommend a 
senior cat.﻿
comments.author: Kiri Celebkiriedhel

comments.text:
i would love getting an older cat but we usually get kittens so we can 
learn them how to act how we want them to;p﻿
comments.author: Natasa Milosevic

comments.text:
I find senior cats charming. I also find it to be an interesting dynamic 
that you're caring for a cat that is older than you are﻿
comments.author: MIS315

comments.text: Well done.  I have 3 dogs of my own and foster senior dogs.﻿
comments.author: Mitchell McCreath

comments.text:
Just wanted to give my personal experience of adopting an older cat with 
health issues.
Around seven years ago we took in a stray cat.
He had obviously lived somewhere before - he was neutered and house-trained.
Then his pre-existing health problems started to become apparent.
He had recurring intestinal problems that were finally diagnosed as a 
distended upper intestine.
We spent a small fortune on vet bills and diligently administered his 
medication daily.
He became a beloved family pet and we were all sad when he unexpectedly 
died.
But we found solace in the fact that for four years he was our family cat 
that loved us and was loved by us.
And that is good enough a reason.﻿
comments.author: Eric Blair

comments.text:
My cat Misty is now 16 years-old and I've had her since she was a kitten. 
Over the years she gets more and more cuddly and sweet the older she gets 
and it's great!﻿
comments.author: Kelsey Rourke

comments.text:
My first rescue was a 7 year old DLH. I am so thankful that I first decided 
to adopt an older cat, because every single point you touched in is true. I 
later adopted a younger cat, who I love just as much, but had an entire new 
set of challenges than what I had with my older cat. I am 100% an advocate 
of older cats. ﻿
comments.author: ch0costory

comments.text:
When I was looking for a cat a year ago I told myself no kittens, my cat 
Maddie who I lost a year before was three when we adopted her, I am going 
to get an older cat like Maddie. When I was looking for a new cat I 
searched the pounds but made no connections. I was going to give up when I 
walked into a pet store one day to get my dogs food and a cat was sitting 
there staring me down. Her cage was sitting above a litter of kittens and I 
knew she had been there for far too long (This is a pet store that holds 
cats when the shelters are overcrowded, not mill cats.) When I asked they 
told me she was a year and a half old and she already had kittens, (so 
great she had kittens and the owners threw her out like trash) and she had 
been in that cage for eight months. They gave me her for free because they 
were so desperate for her to leave.﻿
comments.author: Kat

comments.text:
I love this! I work/volunteer at a free roaming (little to no cages) cat 
shelter and every day its where are your kittens straight out of the womb. 
and of course the next question I ask them is what personality are you more 
looking for. 90% of the time they want one more sweet mellow and cuddly. 
but sorry to say in the five years I have been there I have NEVER seen a 
mellow kitten unless they where sick or injured. and a lot of people think 
differently because they come in to the shelter around 3:00 pm - 5:00 pm 
 as what we like to call "nap time" but if you come in any time between 9:00 
am - 2:00 pm you will see a bunch of kittens bouncing off the walls and 
rearranging the furniture.  ﻿
comments.author: Karl Halder

comments.text: I just adopted an old cat, and this helped me a lot, thanks :)﻿
comments.author: akanematsuo

comments.text:
I actually prefer older animals, to be honest. One of my cats, Tabby, I got 
when she was ten. Best cat ever. Only started having problems when she got 
some kind of disease and had to be put down. :(﻿
comments.author: Jessica Foster

comments.text:
This makes me so sad, when i was adopting my cat 4 years ago. I wanted a 
kitten since this was the first pet i was getting as an adult. The people 
there kept pushing me to get an older cat, and i didnt understand why. It 
even annoyed me. I understand now why they were doing it. I already have 
two cats, but if i ever adopt again i will get an older cat. I dont regret 
the cat i got at that time, she was 3 months old, but shes the sweetest cat 
in the world. My second cat was a teen when i adopted her, a malnourished 
street cat, who was being bullied by the other neighborhood cats, they 
wouldnt let her eat!﻿
comments.author: th1smomentisfate

comments.text:
TBH i don't really want a kitten, I'd much prefer an older mature cat or a 
middle age cat. I'm just afraid they won't be as passionate as a kitten 
since a kitten's bond is grown since a really young age. Can a powerful 
bond still exist from adopted older cats?﻿
comments.author: mechwarreir2

comments.text:
Yes, most definitely! We adopted one of our cats when he was 16 human years 
old and his owner didn't want him any more. We were lucky to share his life 
for just under 4 years before he died. We were told he was an outdoor cat 
who would refuse to come indoors, yet for us he never wanted to go outside. 
He was a lap cat, for the first time in his life, and he used to sleep 
above our heads. I remember laying in bed the first night all our 4 cats 
were allowed to be together.  He was on the floor at the side of the bed, 
miaowing because he was the only cat who wasn't on the bed with us but he 
simply daredn't jump up because of how he had been treated before. My 
partner lifted him up and he immediately stopped miaowing, cuddled up 
between us and started purring loudly. He was so happy that night, like his 
dreams had come true. His personality changed and he blossomed into a 
friendly, loving cat who adored being with us. He followed us around 
everywhere in the house and even used to sit at the side of my head when I 
was having a bath! The only time he stopped purring was when he slept.

He died in October 2012, and we still miss him every day, but we know that 
he enjoyed his life with us - we made him the centre of our world and he 
thrived with such attention, and paid us back a thousand times over.

I honestly think you get more back from adopting an older cat. The ones 
you've lived with since they were kittens have only every known happiness, 
the older ones might have experienced hardship, unhappiness or a lack of 
love. They respond so positively when they finally get to experience the 
good things in life, and they pay you back with lots of affection. 
Obviously, some cats are more reserved, you simply have to make sure the 
shelter knows what sort of cat you're looking for and they will advise you 
accordingly.
comments.author: shedevil50337

comments.text: im adopting a 4 year old cat and it was homeless ps i loved me﻿
comments.author: Ben Walker

comments.text:
But she was like any other cat play full, loving, happy her name was Jenny 
she was black and white fluffy long fur﻿
comments.author: Jaimie Blake

comments.text:
I love cats of all ages my cat of 18 years had bent front legs because she 
was squished in her mother ﻿
comments.author: Jaimie Blake

comments.text: you make me sad﻿
comments.author: Jamari Sivels

comments.text: IKR! Old cats need love as well =)﻿
comments.author: Kat Anton

comments.text:
my family has recently adopted an older cat (around 10 years old) and he is 
WONDERFUL!!
poor guy had a shitty life too, his first family (a couple) had abandoned 
him during a really cold winter and fortunately this very old lady took him 
in, but she died a few months back and whoever cleared her place left him 
outside with his little cat bed : (
a neighbour who used to leave him food outside told me this story and we 
just couldnt leave him out there! we brought him in and were quite scared 
itd be troublesome because we have a dog (a 9 year old bichon girl) but 
they just do NOT care ;D they sniff each other sometimes and thats that!
he started using his litter box right away too! we had a few problems 
getting him to use a scratch post but we figured out because he might have 
some arthritis he prefers a horizontal scratch post instead ; ) 
the only real problem is his teeth are in a pretty bad shape so we'll have 
to take them out and thats some vet bills (which i promised to cover for my 
mother) but what can you do.... he gives back so much love! : D﻿
comments.author: Zombiesfromjupiter

comments.text:
Adopting in general is a good thing. If I find a loving older kitty, I'd 
snatch them up right away. My friend's cat Nemo was adopted as an older 
cat, and he's a great little guy, strange as all hell, but a very loving 
cat.﻿
comments.author: BRBhorror

comments.text:
The older cats that I have adopted seem to be more thankful for their new 
home. I love them <3﻿
comments.author: diamondlightningg

comments.text:
We recently adopted Sallie, 7ish years old (she was so sad and in the 
shelter for upwards of 6 months but at least with really great and caring 
volunteers). She has a huuuuuge and sweet personality; very conversational 
and dynamic little smarty pants. When I get home from work, today's job 
since she's finally comfortable with me and out of her safe room (it's been 
almost 2 weeks of acclimating) and can chill in the basement, is to build 
her jumping pads all over the walls of my studio (her safe room) out of 
plywood, free scrap carpet and "L" brackets. She's middle aged but no lack 
of bubbling energy with this one.
Here's a video of her first day exploring out of the safe room.
https://vimeo.com/116033845

Cheers! Shelters are one of the hardest places (for me at least) to visit 
but when you get to meet little gems like Sallie who looked like she'd be 
terrified forever and then to see them open up and start to enjoy life 
again...  It's a trip. Long and patient trip but such a gratifying 
metamorphosis into a new best friend who'll stop at nothing to keep your 
lap warm. Getting on in years means very little. ﻿
comments.author: miinyoo

comments.text:
I adopted a cat who is 11 years old now and she couldn't be happier! She 
adapted to our apartment well and she basically plays on her own time. She 
is extremely cuddly and she loves to lay on our faces! lol. we really got 
lucky with her and I certainly wouldn't hesitate to adopt an older cat 
again﻿
comments.author: Angel Capo

comments.text:
I am 12 years old and I understand this totally! On the shelter website, I 
always look at the adult or senior cats. However, if none of the senior 
cats are a good fit for my family, then I will look at the adult or the 
younger ones. There's no point in adopting a senior cat, if he/she will not 
fit in with your family and then you just have to return them. So I believe 
that you should see if any of the older cats fit your family, and if not, 
don't adopt one! It won't do any good to return the cat.﻿
comments.author: Cherry Blossoms

comments.text:
Someone makes a video saying only adopt older pets (not saying its you), 
fast forward to a few years...
Their next video: The advantages of a younger cat/kitten﻿
comments.author: Redstone Creeper

comments.text: *slow blink to Jackson*﻿
comments.author: TheMassiveToe

comments.text:
i always get older animals or teens. Even with issues. never regretted it! 
Adopting them is heart warming!! for the part that you say that you get 
what you get. never been true for me. I had an aggressive cat she was 
missed treated not good with animals and had trust issue. Now she cuddles 
give kisses.  Nice with our older cat plays with our skinny pigs. She`s 
great. took a bit of time doh for trust. was hard work but i think that's 
why we love her so much. she is a bit scared of visitors but she is not 
dangerous. poor thing was found taped in a box with her kittens almost died 
and spend 4 years in foster care . got adopted a couple of time but always 
came back because they were scared of her. but i donno how i did but she is 
a happy family kitty now. Animal rescue was very happy and shock that i did 
n`t bring her back. there is always hope ! for cats the trick for me was to 
never let them win with there anger. even if she scared the shit out of me 
for the first month everytime she hisss or scratch me i ran to her grab her 
and give her a kiss and hug. trust me i was scared she would scratch my 
face off but after 4 times she started purring and it got better every day 
then she came to me more and more! ( i even flip the bed once so she would 
n`t win) ( hey its my house number one and number two YOU ARE GOING TO BE 
LOVED THAT`S IT!!!!! ) ﻿

comments.text:
There is an 8 1/2 year old cat at the local humane society. I worry that

I adopted my first older cat today. She's six years old and her name its

comments.author: Teresa Mejia

comments.text:
Hi Guys, I adopted a 1,5 y old female cat from a girl who could  not have 
kept her. We have been living together for 1 a year now, there a lots of 
pros and cons. The pros are, she is dealing with the litter box pretty 
well, can be alone for long period of time, but I try to play with her  as 
many as I can. So she behaves well, but she does not allow me to pet or 
touch here, she keeps the 1 meter distance between us, and is afraid of me, 
I do not know why. She seems does not intend to accept me, and regards her 
former keeper the only one or I really do not know. Any idea? I am pleasing 
her as much as I can, but she allowed the girl to pet or touch her.  any 
idea? /sorry for my broken English/ greetings from Hungary﻿

comments.text: Amazing video!﻿

comments.text:
I got three kittens for my birthday and they're adorable little angels now

comments.text: Are KITTY Norman is 4 years old﻿
comments.author: Kathy Stewart

comments.text: I adopted a 1 1/2-2 years old cat﻿
comments.author: OlihamGaming

comments.text:
Brilliantly put. After adopting a senior dog I can say that the 
companionship is rewarding and enriching and I would consider this true for 
any older animal.﻿
comments.author: Elka Ophiuchus

comments.text: Whats that thing around your neck?﻿
comments.author: Kei Zhang

comments.text:
Being someone who has not had cats since I was quite young. I am moving to 
an apparent where i won't be able to keep my dogs. This  just kills me! I 
love my dogs (who are elderly and I do have the same worries for them) 
Anyway, the apartment does allow cats. What age of cat would you recommend 
for me? I don't feel like I could get a senior because my heart is already 
breaking at losing my dogs. I don't want a kitten because I want a cuddly 
cat and I don't want to deal with a kitten whom, I don't know how they will 
act. Would you think that a cat between the ages of 1 and about 5 would be 
good for someone like me?﻿
comments.author: Lucailey

comments.text:
YES! i get stray cats come into my clinic weekly (some are severely 
injured) and majority of the cats injured or not between the age of 1-5 are 
the most adorable and sweetest cats i have ever met! One tortoiseshell cat 
had a broken non displaced pelvis which would heal over time is currently 
at my clinic and you can literally use her as a pillow she loves cuddles 
and is absolutely adorable! One good thing about not getting a kitten is 
you wont have to worry about litter training them as most shelters/rescues 
do that for you :)
comments.author: tigger1995Magi

comments.text:
If anyone is worried that a older cat might be costly or that they will 
die, just remember this will be the kitten in 5-10 years. Pets cost alot of 
money no matter what the age. You would want your pets to be taken care of 
in their own age.

After my great uncle died, my family got his two pekeignes. They were 12 
and 15 when we got them, and they where wonderful dogs. unfortunatity they 
died. But we were able to give them a good home in their last years of 
their lives.﻿
comments.author: Qwerty Qaz

comments.text:
I adopted a 11 years old cat about a month ago. He's such a sweetheart but 
i can absolutely see that he's been through a lot. I just hope he'll soon 
feel even more at home here. <3 ﻿

comments.text:
I would adopt an older cat, but I currently have a 9month old kitten and do

and asked their opinion and they said anything 2 years or younger.﻿
comments.author: M “AngrySuccubus” Kennedy

comments.text:

comments.text:
so true the adults are the best  got two adult gingers I adopted  over

comments.author: sarah ollie

comments.text:
i have a question when cats get older do they sometimes go insane my cat 
did BUT sje has epilcictic sezuires and she usally has them on our roof and 
falls down poor baby but shes tuff so is that just from all the falls or 
cuz shes old﻿
comments.author: Jake  Bolen

comments.text:
I had an older cat, I named her Syanka, the Bulgarian word for Shadow. She 
really was my shadow, followin me everywhere. I didn't know she was old 
when I got her, the shelter told me she was 1 years old and in perfect 
health, just really skinny. That wasn't the case. Both vets I took her too 
told me she wasn't a one year old but a teenage cat, and she wasn't in 
perfect health. She had a high thyroid, so she ate up to three friskey cans 
a day, and she had a horrible teeth issue that cost us $1,000 to fix. I 
recently lost her, possibly from pancreas cancer, I don't know, but I will 
say this: even through all the ups and downs I had with her, if given the 
chance, I would do this all over again and give her as much love, if not 
more, than I gave her the first time.﻿
comments.author: KikidoGames

comments.text:
I'm so sad this reminds me of my cat. He died at age 17 in October. He was 
my favorite cat.﻿
